{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3601013,"name":"Dustin Spicuzza","username":"virtuald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T04:35:47.532Z","cooked":"

With a new controller coming in 2027 being used by both FTC and FRC, we’re expecting that the number of python users will go up, especially with blockly generating python code (see the systemcore slides). Right now most RobotPy work is still primarily done by me – and even though I’m not very good at delegating, I’d like that to change!

There’s lots of room for contributions, especially if you’re a self-starter who wants to make an impact. Here’s some of the things that we need help with:

  • VSCode Extension - do you know typescript? Every year teams ask for RobotPy VSCode integration. I’d love to see a VSCode extension, but we need someone to make it happen.
  • Installer improvements - do you know python packaging? The robotpy-installer project has a lot of open usability improvement bugs that would be great for someone to work on. For the 2027 controller I expect that we’ll probably move to deploying to a virtualenv – how that will work is up in the air, and you could help define it.
  • Unit Testing - do you like breaking things on purpose? There are lots of tests in allwpilib, and very few tests in mostrobotpy. Everything probably works, but if you help us write tests we can catch more problems before they reach teams.
  • Robot Tests - do you know pytest? pyfrc has robot integration test support, and it’s better this year… but it also has flaws that need to be addressed. Take a look at the pyfrc github issue tracker.
  • Documentation - do you like writing? I don’t, and it shows.

Whenever I have ideas that I’d like to eventually get to for RobotPy, I try to put them on github. Take a look and see if there’s anything that seems interesting and make a pull request.

virtuald:

Documentation - do you like writing?

(Raises hand) Especially as SystemCore dates approach, I’d be happy to help here, if nothing else out of a sense of self preservation

My availability will be a bit up and down over the next 12 months or so, but if you find a larger bucket of work that needs thought about, feel free to @ me in an issue and I can start discussion of how to break it down and tackle it.

We are going to be transitioning to using robotpy for this next season, so I would be more than happy help out where I can. I think I can plug in on the robotpy-installer and (documentation or testing) as well.

gerthworm:

(Raises hand) Especially as SystemCore dates approach, I’d be happy to help here, if nothing else out of a sense of self preservation

With documentation, there’s two large buckets of work:

  • Examples examples examples examples. There’s still lots of documentation pages that only have Java/C++ examples.
  • Installation documentation is fine, but there are still questions on CD about it so it can be better. Probably some improvement needed here, but what those improvements are is rather ill-defined.

How opposed to a PyCharm plugin are you? I am really unsure of how a VSCode extension would work in this case, at least similarly to WPILibs existing VSCode but a PyCharm one could be built similarly to @Javaru’s InteliJ plugin.

I just graduated off a new-to-Python team and I’d love to start helping. Getting started seems pretty daunting. Any advice or anything I should know ahead of time?

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T16:04:02.726Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":226,"readers_count":225,"score":50.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":500241,"topic_slug":"robotpy-looking-for-a-few-good-contributors","display_username":"Ethan Grieshop","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":62698,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"4611 Programmer + Driver"},"post_url":"/t/robotpy-looking-for-a-few-good-contributors/500241/8","custom_user_title":"4611 Programmer + Driver","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3601519,"name":"Dustin Spicuzza","username":"virtuald","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T16:59:29.294Z","cooked":"

I think an eventual goal would be to integrate with the existing WPILib VSCode extension, so a vscode extension would probably have more impact?

I’m not opposed to a pycharm extension, but either way someone would need to do it.

CakeDeer6:

I just graduated off a new-to-Python team and I’d love to start helping. Getting started seems pretty daunting. Any advice or anything I should know ahead of time?

Generally, you’ll be more productive if you’re doing something you find interesting and can put your head around. Trying to fix things that personally annoy you can be a good motivator too.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T17:21:33.645Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":209,"readers_count":208,"score":76.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":500241,"topic_slug":"robotpy-looking-for-a-few-good-contributors","display_username":"Dustin Spicuzza","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":11063,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer"},"post_url":"/t/robotpy-looking-for-a-few-good-contributors/500241/10","custom_user_title":"RobotPy Guy, WPILib Developer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3601598,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-23T17:57:43.883Z","cooked":"

To add onto this, we are planning on having vscode hosted on the controller in 2027 for on-controller development, so vscode extension support that provides command-line-free operation for creating and deploying Python robot code would be useful for both on-robot and desktop development use cases.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-04-23T17:57:59.139Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":195,"readers_count":194,"score":54.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":500241,"topic_slug":"robotpy-looking-for-a-few-good-contributors","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":11063,"username":"virtuald","name":"Dustin Spicuzza","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/robotpy-looking-for-a-few-good-contributors/500241/11","custom_user_title":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3608611,"name":"Justin Buist","username":"Justin_Buist","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/j/c77e96/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-01T03:34:03.498Z","cooked":"

I’ve been tinkering with how to bootstrap a robotpy project with uv this evening and, while I can do it, it doesn’t seem like something I’d want to smash in front of a new user.

And I feel like if there was just a “yes, we all use ‘uv’ for robotpy” maybe it’d be easier.

The thing that works for me is uv init robotpy-example then from within the project uv add robotpy followed with mv pyproject.toml orig; uv run robotpy init; cat orig >> pyproject.toml; rm orig

With that I’ve got a nice uv venv to work with.

I have no idea how to make it simpler but I wish I did.

I’m not well versed in the entire universe of python package managers, but uv has not ticked me off yet and that’s saying something.

I’m thinking of this mostly because I’m wondering what a VSCode extension would do. My first thought is bootstrapping a project.

Next would be adding in a vendordep manager which in the Python case is just a pyproject.toml modification. Although in that case the default of just putting them in there and letting users uncomment them is pretty friendly to me. For something you’re coding up. And lets you pin versions once you know the syntax.

And if we’re going to be modifying the pyproject.toml why not offer an option to turn on some serious linting and type checking? That seems like it’d be less hassle than vendordeps.

Just thinking out loud. Don’t read too much into my ramblings.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-05-01T03:52:30.422Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":152,"readers_count":151,"score":30.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":500241,"topic_slug":"robotpy-looking-for-a-few-good-contributors","display_username":"Justin Buist","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":11063,"username":"virtuald","name":"Dustin Spicuzza","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/virtuald/{size}/65268_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24678,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/robotpy-looking-for-a-few-good-contributors/500241/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3608631,"name":"Adam Gaddis","username":"agaddis02","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/3ec8ea/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-05-01T04:27:28.111Z","cooked":"

yeah, it’s easier to actually just do robotpy init first, and then just copy the project section at the top of .toml, because that is all that uv is looking for.

I think the flow that makes the most since is taking advantage of how uv uses “tools”.

So you can run uvx robotpy init which will run robotpy init without actually installing robotpy at all.

robotpy init then just needs to also include a [project] section in the pyproject.toml. It currently only includes the [tool.robotpy]. UV doesn’t need to have owned the pyproject.toml file, it just needs it to have a [project] section in it.

So once you add the basic project section then you can use uv freely.

So my exact current steps were:

  1. uvx robotpy init
  2. hx pyproject.toml (how ever you want to edit this) and add basic project section
[project]
name = "quick-test"
version = "0.1.0"
description = "Add your description here"
readme = "README.md"
requires-python = ">=3.13"
dependencies = []
  1. uv add robotpy

And then everything works nicely.

i wouldn’t worry too much about docs, you can use deepwiki which crawls your repo and generates documentation that I would rate a solid 6-7/10 but is a good starting point to improve on and the ai rag or whatever’s going on works p nice as well. works extremely well on monorepos like wpilib’s and python code (for obv reasons).

virtuald:

Installer improvements - do you know python packaging? The robotpy-installer project has a lot of open usability improvement bugs that would be great for someone to work on. For the 2027 controller I expect that we’ll probably move to deploying to a virtualenv – how that will work is up in the air, and you could help define it.

I create troll programs to mess with peoples computers and have had to delve into python packaging and shipping to other devices a fair bit. I’m willing to donate my time to help on this front.

I have not worked with Robotpy before, but feel confident in my ability to learn it to help you out!

virtuald:

Unit Testing - do you like breaking things on purpose? There are lots of tests in allwpilib, and very few tests in mostrobotpy. Everything probably works, but if you help us write tests we can catch more problems before they reach teams.

I’d be happy to take a look and implement some geometry unit tests once these darn AP exams finish .
